title: The Letters of Robert Burns

snippet: The "Ochil Hills"[56] you shallprobably have next week for yourself.

title: The Letters of Robert Burns
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: The "Ochil Hills"[56] you shallprobably have next week for yourself.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: To the north and east are the Ochil Hills, and the windings of the Forth through the Carse of Stirling, with its fertile fields, luxuriant woods, and stately mansions.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The Ochil Hills arc now well seen on the right.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Ascending the first opening on the right (Wemyss Place), we reach Queen Street, the upper windows of which command an excellent prospect of the Frith of Forth, the shores of Fife, and the Ochil Hills, and in some states of the atmosphere, the peaks of the Grampians.

title: Letters from Thomas Percy, D.D. :
snippet: It was dedicated to St Magridin, whose church, now called Exmagirdle, anciently Ecclesia Magridin, stands at the east end of the Ochil Hills in Strathern, five miles

title: The Edinburgh gazetteer, or geographical dictionary ...
snippet: Ochil Hills, a range of lofty mountains in Scotland, which begin in Perthshire, and stretch eastward into the county of Fife.

title: We four.
author: Rees, L. L.
snippet: We took the famous Edmondston Walk, so named after the gentleman who constructed  it, and through the castle-garden, viewing from the ramparts the Campsie Hills at the south, the Ochil Hills at the north and east, and the Highlands in the west.

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: To the north, the Grampian and Ochil Hills bound the view; while to the west the frowning summits of Ben Lomond, Ben Nevis, and Benvenue rise to the skies and form a barrier to

title: Twelve thousand miles over land and sea;
author: Hutton, William
snippet: The river Forth, fringed with poplar, ash, and willow, and winding through green meadows, and fields of ripening grain, forms thirteen beautiful curves, as it rolls past Stirling Castle! Then, the Vale of Menteith on the west, the Campsie on the south, the Ochil Hills on the north, and Bannockburn — memorable as the scene of a bloody battle fought in 1314, by Edward II.

title: Glances on the wing at foreign lands,
author: Hoyt, James M.
snippet: Still further north and sweeping around to the east bounding the horizon,  are the Ochil Hills — pictured with green fields and patches of purple heather and bare rock.

title: Glances on the wing at foreign lands,
author: Hoyt, James M.
snippet: Ochil Hills.

title: Europe, through a woman's eye /
author: Culler, Lucy Yeend.
snippet: The atmosphere was clear and bright (a rare thing for Scotland) and we could distinctly see Ben Lomond, Ben Venue, Ben A'an, Ben Ledi, Ben Voirlich, Uam-Var, the Ochil Hills and the winding Forth River, the Campasie Hills, a ruined Abbey, the Wallace Monument, Abbey Craig, the Bridge of Allan and the old "Field of Bannockburn," where Bruce gained the victory which liberated Scotland.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: I was storm-stayed two days at the foot of the Ochil Hills, with Mr. Tait of Harvieston and Mr. Johnston of Alva ; but was so well pleased that I shall certainly spend a day on the banks of the Devon as I return.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: Tuesday morning, [28M Aug.'\ Breakfast with Captain  Forrester— leave Stirling— Ochil Hills— Devon River— Forth and Teith— Allan River— Strathallan, a fine country but little improven — Ardoch Camp — Cross Earn to Crieflf— Dine, and go to Arbruchil ; cold reception  at Arbruchil — A most romantically pleasant ride up Earn, by Auchertyre and Comrie — Sup at Crieflf.

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: From that part of the ramparts styled the " Queen's Look-out," since Queen Victoria visited the castle, is a most magnificent view, including that part of the valley of the Forth we traversed from Aberfoyle and still farther westward, taking in the vale of Monteith, and bounded by Ben Lomond to the extreme left ; then, rising in due order to the right, Ben Venue, Ben A'an, Ben Ledi, the cone of Ben Vorlich, Uamvar, the Ochil Hills to the north and east and the Campsie Hills to the south ; Sanchieburn, where James III, was defeated by his insurgent nobles in 1488, the house near by still standing where he was assassinated the day after the battle ; to the north the field of Stirling, where Wallace gained his first victory over the English in 1297, and farther on, the upland slope of Sheriff Muir, the scene of the battle between the Earl of Mar for the Pretender and the English forces under the Duke of Argyle, in 1715.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: Twicethe Tay makes a breach through the mountains,—once at Dunkeld, and again in the Ochil Hills, where Perth is situated ; and,lastly, where it narrows before discharging itself into the sea, liesthe town of Dundee.

title: Travels in Scotland: translated from the German. With notes by the translator [John Kesson]
author: Kohl, Johann Georg.
snippet: The road, at first, led alongAllandale, at the foot of the Ochil Hills, and by the villages ofLecropt and Dunblane.

title: Notes by the Way; or, what I saw in my rambles
author: Higginson, H. Talbot.
snippet: To the north andeast are the Ochil Hills and the windings of the Forth, and on the southare the Campsie Hills.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
author: Haight, Canniff.
snippet: From my bedroom window I can see theOchil Hills.

title: Here and there in the Home Land. England, Scotland and Ireland as seen by a Canadian. ... Profusely illustrated
